param.name: incoming
param.label: Data containing the ranges to be annotated

param.name: txdb
param.label: TxDb object for the genome of interest

param.name: orgdb
param.label: OrgDb object for the genome of interest

param.name: dist
param.label: Specify the flanking distance to annotate

param.name: promoter_upstream
param.label: Value defining the promoter as some distance upstream from the TSS

param.name: promoter_downstream
param.label: Value defining the promoter as some distance downstream from the TSS

param.name: key_field
param.label: Specify the keytype for name extraction
param.help: Default settings will work for human and mouse genomes, but may not work for other organisms. The keytype should refer to the key type in the OrgDb object, and also correspond to the GENEID of the TxDb object. For example, for S. cerevisiae the keytype should be set to ORF.

param.name: name_field
param.label: Specify the column to use as the gene name
param.help: Default settings will work for human and mouse genomes, but may not work for other organisms.
For example, for S. cerevisiae the column should be set to GENENAME.

param.name: ignore_strand
param.label: Ignore strandedness in data?
param.help: If no is selected, then the annotated features will only be reported if they lie on the same strand as that region

tool.help: Add detailed exon-based annotation to specified genomic regions. This tool adds annotations to a given set of genomic regions in the form of compact character strings specifying the features overlapping and flanking each region. The aim is to determine the genic context of empirically identified regions, for some basic biological interpretation of binding/marking in those regions. All neighboring genes within a specified range are reported, rather than just the closest gene to the region.
